Let $a = 1 + i$ and $b = 4 + 7i.$  The complex number $c$ lies on the line segment connecting $a$ and $b$ so that the distance between $a$ and $c$ is equal to twice the distance between $c$ and $b.$  Find $c.$

inference:
The mistake is in the interpretation of the ratio $|c-a| = 2|c-b|$.  This does *not* mean that $c$ divides the line segment $ab$ in the ratio $2:1$.

Here's a corrected approach:

We found that $c$ lies on the circle $(x-5)^2 + (y-9)^2 = 10$.  This means $c$ is of the form $5 + \sqrt{10} \cos \theta + (9 + \sqrt{10} \sin \theta) i$.

Now, we have
\begin{align*}
|c - a| &= |(5 + \sqrt{10} \cos \theta + (9 + \sqrt{10} \sin \theta) i) - (1 + i)| \\
&= \sqrt{(4 + \sqrt{10} \cos \theta)^2 + (8 + \sqrt{10} \sin \theta)^2},
\end{align*}and
\begin{align*}
|c - b| &= |(5 + \sqrt{10} \cos \theta + (9 + \sqrt{10} \sin \theta) i) - (4 + 7i)| \\
&= \sqrt{(1 + \sqrt{10} \cos \theta)^2 + (2 + \sqrt{10} \sin \theta)^2}.
\end{align*}We want $|c - a| = 2 |c - b|,$ so
\[\sqrt{(4 + \sqrt{10} \cos \theta)^2 + (8 + \sqrt{10} \sin \theta)^2} = 2 \sqrt{(1 + \sqrt{10} \cos \theta)^2 + (2 + \sqrt{10} \sin \theta)^2}.\]Squaring both sides, we get
\[(4 + \sqrt{10} \cos \theta)^2 + (8 + \sqrt{10} \sin \theta)^2 = 4[(1 + \sqrt{10} \cos \theta)^2 + (2 + \sqrt{10} \sin \theta)^2].\]Expanding, we get
\[16 + 8 \sqrt{10} \cos \theta + 10 \cos^2 \theta + 64 + 16 \sqrt{10} \sin \theta + 10 \sin^2 \theta = 4 + 8 \sqrt{10} \cos \theta + 40 \cos^2 \theta + 16 + 16 \sqrt{10} \sin \theta + 40 \sin^2 \theta.\]This simplifies to $30 \cos^2 \theta + 30 \sin^2 \theta = 60,$ so $\cos^2 \theta + \sin^2 \theta = 2.$  Since $\cos^2 \theta + \sin^2 \theta = 1,$ this equation has no solutions.  Therefore, there is $\boxed{\text{no solution}}.$
